user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__thread_per_conn:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__thread_per_conn (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.all_cpus)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-A' or '--all-cpus'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (0 != tool_params.threads)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-t' or '--threads'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.thread_per_conn = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the function contains only the declaration/closing braces and the fprintf calls embedded in the shown conditional blocks; there is no other code after an unconditional return that would be unreachable. The only locations where unreachable code could arise (for this routine) are the conditional early returns and the final assignment/return sequence — these fragments are therefore reported for investigation to determine whether any of the conditions can be statically true for all inputs (making later statements unreachable) or otherwise produce dead code. No other fragments in the function present evidence of unreachable code (there are no unreachable statements following unconditional jumps, no duplicate/never-taken branches outside the reported fragments).
